intro: Quercus aquatica var. attenuata, commonly known as the narrow-leaved water oak, is a variant of the water oak native to the southeastern United States. It is a deciduous tree characterized by its elongated, narrow leaves that are typically 4–8 inches long. The leaves are glossy on the upper surface and lighter in color on the underside, with a serrated margin. It produces small, pale green to reddish-brown acorns that mature in the second year. This species is adapted to wetland environments and is often found in swamps and along riverbanks.
